input_args.examples: {'document_id': ['0006236', '0006236', '0006236', '0002736'], 'document_source': ['GARD', 'GARD', 'GARD', 'GARD'], 'document_url': ['https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/3884/tubular-aggregate-myopathy', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/3884/tubular-aggregate-myopathy', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/3884/tubular-aggregate-myopathy', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/6570/hashimotos-syndrome'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C0410207', 'C0410207', 'C0410207', 'C0677607|C0039082'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T047', 'T047', 'T047', 'T047'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': ['Myopathy, tubular aggregate|Myopathy congenital', 'Myopathy, tubular aggregate|Myopathy congenital', 'Myopathy, tubular aggregate|Myopathy congenital', "Autoimmune thyroiditis|Hashimoto's disease|Thyroiditis, chronic|Hashimoto's struma|Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis"], 'question_id': ['0006236-3', '0006236-4', '0006236-5', '0002736-1'], 'question_focus': ['Tubular aggregate myopathy', 'Tubular aggregate myopathy', 'Tubular aggregate myopathy', "Hashimoto's syndrome"], 'question_type': ['causes', 'inheritance', 'treatment', 'information'], 'question': ['What causes Tubular aggregate myopathy ?', 'Is Tubular aggregate myopathy inherited ?', 'What are the treatments for Tubular aggregate myopathy ?', "What is (are) Hashimoto's syndrome ?"], 'answer': ['What causes tubular aggregate myopathy? Currently, the underlying cause of tubular aggregate myopathy is not known. Some cases appear to be due to dominant mutations in the STIM1 gene.', 'Is tubular aggregate myopathy genetic? It is evident from family history studies that the condition can be passed through families in either an autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive fashion. Some cases appear to be due to dominant mutations in the STIM1 gene. Sporadic cases of tubular aggregate myopathy have also been reported. Sporadic is used to denote either a genetic disorder that occurs for the first time in a family due to a new mutation or the chance occurrence of a non-genetic disorder or abnormality that is not likely to recur in a family.', 'How might tubular aggregate myopathy be treated?', 'Hashimotos syndrome is a form of chronic inflammation that can damage the thyroid, reducing its ability to produce hormones (hypothyroidism). An early sign of the condition may be enlargement of the thyroid (called a goiter), which can potentially interfere with breathing or swallowing. Other signs and symptoms may include tiredness, weight gain, thin and dry hair, joint or muscle pain, constipation, cold intolerance, and/or a slowed heart rate. Affected women may have irregular menstrual periods or difficulty becoming pregnant. Hashimotos syndrome is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the United States. It is more common in women than in men, and it usually appears in mid-adulthood. The exact cause is unknown but it is thought to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment is not always needed, but may include taking synthetic thyroid hormone.']}
